4.content: Idea for an important moment: Record a video for your unborn child when you first find out they're growing inside you.

5.content: Take a pregnancy test at home. If pregnant, most tests will show two strips. Congratulations!

6.content: You may feel unwell; toxicosis and heartburn are common. Follow nutritional advice and talk to your doctor.

7.content: Now is the most crucial period of pregnancy. How your baby develops depends on your lifestyle and proper nutrition.

8.content: Your physician needs data about your blood pressure. Set up reminders for regular measurements.

9.content: Your tummy is nicely rounded. Start measuring it regularly; this information will help your doctor.

10.content: In the next 3 weeks, go for an ultrasound. Doing it now helps prevent potential issues in your child's development.

11.content: Up to 13 weeks of pregnancy is high risk for malformations of the baby. Watch your food intake and overall wellbeing.

12.content: Monitor your weight carefully. This will help avoid possible complications during pregnancy.

13.content: The first trimester of your pregnancy has ended. You still have outstanding items on your checklist.

14.content: Being well rested and actively walking will help avoid many complications during pregnancy.

15.content: Hypertension occurs in 40% of pregnancies. Measure your blood pressure regularly, report results to your doctor.

16.content: Pregnancy increases health issues. Closely monitor any conditions, especially chronic illnesses.

17.content: Take care of your body after childbirth. Now stay active, walk more often, do stretches.

18.content: Baby starts kicking – an important event. Tell your doctor. About 20 weeks between first occurrence and giving birth.

19.content: Your physician needs data about your blood pressure. Set up reminders for regular measurements.

20.content: In 20-24 weeks, a second ultrasound is performed to detect congenital malformations of the fetus. Open Checklist.

21.content: Already feel the baby? Time to track their movement! This is important information for monitoring fetal development.

22.content: Monitor your weight carefully. This will help avoid possible complications during pregnancy.

23.content: Proper nutrition and cutting bad habits reduces risk of complications in your baby's development. Read Nutrition Tips.

24.content: Being well rested and actively walking will help avoid many complications during pregnancy.

25.content: Your baby should move 10-15 times per an hour. Keep kicking in mind, immediately report any abnormalities to your doctor.

26.content: How to tell a real contraction from a fake one? When should you go to the hospital? Read Help in Counting Contractions.

27.content: The second trimester of your pregnancy has ended. You still have outstanding items on your checklist.

28.content: Your physician needs data about your blood pressure. Set up reminders for regular measurements.

29.content: Watch your baby move. Immediately go to the doctor if there is no movement for 12 hours or they seem too active.

30.content: Being well rested and actively walking will help avoid many complications during pregnancy.

31.content: Pay attention to false labor. How do you know if it's that or preterm onset labor? Read Help in Counting Contractions.

32.content: It's time to collect your things for the hospital. Use tips in the App.

33.content: Watch your weight carefully. Extra pounds will complicate childbirth and subsequent recovery.

34.content: How to reduce pain during childbirth? Read Help in Counting contractions.

35.content: You need to closely monitor your blood pressure, especially if you feel worse than usual this week.

36.content: You're going to meet your baby very soon! Hurry to fulfill all the recommendations before going to the hospital.

37.content: Idea for an important moment: Record a video for your baby just before giving birth. Read tips.

38.content: Breathe deeply, change positions more often... What should I do to reduce my pain during contractions?

39.content: Only 5% of children are born on a "reference" period of 40 weeks. Most – 85% – are born a week before or after 40 weeks.

40.content: Take care of everything you need after discharge. Is everything ready for the baby at home? Open Checklists.

41.content: You will be a great mom! Learn how to care for little ones during the first days of their life.
